title: Motorcycle test review seminar
body:
## Summary

Around 160 -170 trainers from around 80 Approved Training Bodies, attended the Motorcycle Test Review Seminar on the 6th July. 

The main issues that came out during the seminar arising from comments made and questions asked, and from the subsequent written questions, were concerns about accessibility of the test and the suggested timescales. There was also concerns about safety if certain elements of the test that are currently carried out off-road were moved on-road but there was overall support for a single event test.  

## Safety

A research contract was let to the Transport Research Laboratory in July 2011. Phase 1 of the research will involve holding independent trials with test level candidates to verify standards, suitability and safety of the proposed new manoeuvres, using mock road layouts at off road sites. Some of the new manoeuvres are different from those in the current module1 test and have been designed to be suitable for on-road as well as off-road sites. Phase 2 of the research, which will follow later, will take place on the road and will identify the criteria for suitable on-road sites and determine the requirements for the safe conduct of the test on-road, so that candidates are not put at unnecessary risk.

## Accessibility

One of the main aims of the test review is to improve accessibility. The key to this is the ability to conduct a single event test on-road. Assuming that the research finds that the test can be carried out safely on-road and suitable roads are identified, then it may be possible to provide tests in gap areas that are currently not served by an off-road MPTC. We are considering new manoeuvres that can be performed in an equivalent way either on-road or off-road and there may be a mixed approach by maintaining the current MMAs and supplementing accessibility by a fully on-road test in those areas that are not currently well served, at least for a transitional period; but the content of the test will be the same for all candidates, wherever it is taken. 

In the meantime, to try and minimise the distance that some learner riders have to travel for their module1 tests, DSA are using casual sites and shared VOSA sites to try and minimise any service gaps. They are also continuing to look at introducing further casual site arrangements, in the areas most affected.

## Timetable

We are moving as quickly as we can to deliver a more accessible test but we need to be sure that any changes we make really do deliver improvements. We don't want to rush into changes that might not work in practice.

The timetable presented at the seminar suggested bringing in the new manoeuvres and a single event test during Winter 2012/13. The research needed to establish the safety and practicality of the new manoeuvres, will take place in autumn 2011 (Phase 1) and spring 2012 (Phase 2). There will also need to be a public consultation on the proposed changes, which we plan to hold mid 2012 in the light of the findings of the Phase 2 research. 

Subject to the outcome of the consultation, we will then need to make new legislation to implement the new test, which is likely to take until at least autumn 2012. So Winter 2012/13 is the earliest possible time for implementation of the new test. We would expect to introduce a single event test and the new maneouvres in all test locations at this time.

The new manoeuvres would initially be provided in on-road locations, only in gap areas that are not well served by the off-road test centres but those off-road test centres would still be used where available. This will be a transition period, as the new manoeuvres are monitored to ensure their safety in practice. The manoeuvres would then be transferred from off-road test centres to on-road locations, as suitable sites are identified in each test location around the country. This will take place over a period of time, while suitable sites are identified in every test location in all parts of the country, before the transition to on-road testing in all areas is complete. There would need to be on-going dialogue with stakeholders over this process and review of the initial implementation to ensure any issues are resolved.

## Download Q&A

  * [Motorcycle test review seminar - Q&A's (PDF, 69 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/motorcycles/motorcycle-test-review-q-a.pdf)
attachment_1_title: Motorcycle test review seminar - Q&A's

title: Update on the Motorcycle Test Review
summary: Update on the Motorcycle Test Review which has been considering alternative ways of providing a motorcycle test.
body:
## Summary

The Motorcycle Test Review has been considering alternative ways of providing a motorcycle test that maintains UK riding standards and improves accessibility and safety for test candidates, while meeting the requirements of the European legislation. We have made progress in identifying potential alternative manoeuvres and the kinds of location that could be suitable. Work is underway to evaluate these options to see if they are feasible, safe and deliverable in all areas.

## Download the document

title: Motorists' Forum terms of reference and meeting minutes
summary: Minutes and terms of reference for the Motorists' Forum.
body:
## Summary

It is important for Ministers to understand and take full account of the views of those who use and manage roads to inform work on both longer term strategies and short term interventions affecting road users and/or aimed at improving the performance of roads.

The Motorists' Forum is intended to be the primary regular channel through which road users and other key stakeholders from the roads and motoring sector contribute to government thinking on priorities for and performance of roads. The Forum will both have a role in helping to shape topics of current interest, and setting a longer term strategic direction for roads and motoring policies.

This page features terms of reference for the Motorists' Forum. It also provides access to minutes from the Motorists Forum Sub-Group.

## Motorists' Forum terms of reference

title: Night Flying Restrictions at Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted Airports
summary: Background information regarding the decision to extend the existing night noise regime at Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted for two years.
body:
Under Section 78 of the Civil Aviation Act 1982, the government sets noise controls at Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted Airports. With regard to night noise, these measures include a restriction on the number of movements and a quota count system. A movement is either a take off or landing. The quota count system works by allocating points according to how noisy an aircraft is. Aircraft are certified by the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) according to the noise they produce. The current night noise regime for these airports was announced in June 2006 and came into force in October 2006. It ends on 28 October 2012.

The government has decided to extend the existing night noise regime at these airports for two years until the end of summer season 2014, when a new regime will come into force.

The night flying restrictions are divided into summer and winter seasons. The summer season is the period of British Summer Time in any one year. The winter season is the period between the end of British Summer Time in one year and the start of British Summer Time in the next.

For the Summer 2012 season, which commences on 25 March 2012 and ends on 28 October 2012, the movement limits and quota points allowance for the airports are:

Airport Movement Limits Noise Quota Points

Heathrow
3250
5100

Gatwick
11200
6200

Stansted
7000
4650

These movement limits and noise quota points apply to the night quota period which is 23.30 to 06.00.

The movement limits and noise quota points allowance for summer 2013 and summer 2014 will remain the same as for summer 2012, as set out in the table above.

For winter 2012/2013 and 2013/2014 the movement limits and quota points allowance for the airports are:

Airport Movement Limits Noise Quota Points

Heathrow
2550
4080

Gatwick
3250
2000

Stansted
5000
3310

All other aspects of the current regime will remain in place during the two year extension period.

## Indicative Timetable for Replacing Night Flying Regime

Date  

March 2012
Announcement of two year extension to current regime.

Summer 2012
Consultation on draft Aviation Policy Framework, including general policy on night noise.

Autumn 2012
First stage consultation on new night flights regime. To include a review of the costs and benefits of night flights, including an expert assessment from CAA of current literature on aviation night noise health impacts. It will also consider the 2011 night noise contours required under the European Environmental Noise Directive and will seek detailed evidence on the effectiveness of the current regime and on airlines' fleet replacement plans.

October 2012
Current restrictions extended for 24 months.

Spring 2013
Publication of final Aviation Policy Framework (including overall night noise policy).

Summer 2013
Second stage night noise consultation carried out following publication of final Aviation Policy Framework. This will include proposed restrictions for the next regime.

March/April 2014
Announcement of new regime.

October 2014
Beginning of new regime.

## Related documents

  * [Statement: Night Flying Restrictions at Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted Airports](http://www.dft.gov.uk/news/statements/villiers-20120326a/)

title: Noise exposure contours around London airports
summary: Noise exposure reports and contours for London airports (Heathrow- Gatwick and Stansted).
body:
## Summary

The Environmental Research and Consultancy Department (ERCD) of the Civil Aviation Authority estimates the noise exposures around the London airports (Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted) on behalf of the Department for Transport. The magnitude and extent of the aircraft noise around these airports are depicted on maps by contours of constant aircraft noise index (Leq) values. The contours are generated by a computer model validated with noise measurements, which calculates the emissions and propagation of noise from arriving and departing air traffic.

## Detail

ERCD produce annual reports on noise exposure contours at Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted and previous copies of these - back to 1997- are available on this website. These are detailed reports and essential reading for those wishing to understand both how noise exposure contours are produced and how they should be interpreted.

The annual reports include small scale diagrams of noise exposure contours which provide an overall impression of their proximity to major towns.

For those wishing to see more detailed representation of noise exposure contours on the ground, ERCD also produces contours overlaid on larger scale Ordnance Survey paper maps ( 1:50,000 ) or, more recently, in AutoCad DXF format (previously supplied on CD-ROM), the latter primarily used by specialist users such as town planners, consultants etc. Both of these have traditionally been available for purchase from the Department as described in the annual reports.

## Change to presentation of 2005 contours onwards

Annual reports for Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted are available on the website as before.

With effect from 2005, additional representation of noise exposure contours on Ordnance Survey maps has been made available on this website in two formats.

## PDF

**For the non specialist user** in particular, a PDF version of each of the large scale Ordnance Survey maps is available for viewing and downloading. Please note, however, that these are large documents and may take some time to download.

  * [Contours on OS maps](http://www.dft.gov.uk/publications/noise-exposure-contours-on-os-maps-2008-2009)

## AutoCad DXF

**For the specialist user** requiring greater detail, AutoCad DXF files are available on the website for download. (These allow the user to plot the contours on any scale of map).

Please note that in order to gain the best reproduction of contours on a larger scale Ordnance Survey map, it is necessary to have software that is capable of reading DXF files.

Please also note that in view of the large size of the files, they have been compressed using WinZip and will need to be 'unzipped' after being downloaded.

  * [DXF contours for specialist user](http://www.dft.gov.uk/publications/dxf-contours-for-specialist-user-2008-09)

## Printed Maps

Contours overlaid on large scale Ordnance Survey paper maps (1:50,000) continue to be available, at a charge, as described in the annual reports. Although the information/scale presented is exactly same as in the PDF version (see above), the printed maps are larger.

## Noise exposure reports and contours for London airports (Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted)

###2011

### 2009

  * [Noise exposure contours for Gatwick Airport (PDF, 7168 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/noise-exposure-contours/noisegatwick09.pdf)

title: Department for Transport and NDPB structure charts, organisational and salary disclosure data
summary: Department for Transport and Non Departmental Public Bodies (NDPB) structure charts and organisational data
body:
## Background

Organisation structure charts (organograms) include:

  * structure of the department/body down to directorate level
  * positions of all Senior Civil Servant (SCS) Pay Band 2 and above (or equivalent)
  * names of SCS Pay Band 2 and above
  * salaries of all Pay Band 2 and above
  * job titles of SCS Pay Band 1 and 1A (or equivalent)
  * reporting numbers of staff within directorates (FTE) and total salary costs of SCS1 teams

Organisational data CSV files include:

  * SCS staff posts - name, grade, job title, team function, parent department, organisation, unit, contact details, reports, salary cost of reports

Salary disclosure data CSV files include:

  * SCS staff salaries - name, grade, job title, FTE, parent department, organisation, unit, actual pay floor, actual pay ceiling
  * Junior staff FTE - parent department, organisation, unit, reporting SCS, grade, number of posts FTE

## Department for Transport

  * The organisation chart is being updated

title: London and South East 'top ten' overcrowded train services
summary: The ten most overcrowded rail services in spring 2010 and autumn 2010.
body:
The Department collects rail passenger counts from train operating companies (TOCs) to monitor train crowding levels. All franchises let by the DfT require the train operator to address crowding and to plan their timetables in such a way as to ensure, as far as possible, that crowding is not unduly concentrated on any particular route or individual service. The tables included in the papers below show the ten most overcrowded services.

## Download

  * [London and South East 'top ten' overcrowded train services: spring 2011 (PDF, 33KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/london-south-east-overcrowded-train-services/overcrowded-trains-south-east-spring-2011.pdf)
  * [London and South East 'top ten' overcrowded train services: spring and autumn 2010 (PDF, 68KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/london-south-east-overcrowded-train-services/overcrowded-trains-south-east.pdf)
attachment_1_title: London and South East €˜top ten' overcrowded train services: spring 2011
attachment_2_title: London and South East €˜top ten' overcrowded train services: spring and autumn 2010

title: Department for Transport partnership with the overseas territories
summary: The Department for Transport has published its own paper to strengthen its relationship with overseas territories.
body:
## Summary

As part of HMG's White Paper on the Overseas Territories (OTs) due to be published (June, 2012), the Department for Transport is publishing its own paper to strengthen its relationship with these Overseas Territories. This paper primarily focuses on Maritime and Aviation issues.

  * [DfT's work with the Overseas Territories (PDF, 126 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/overseas-territories/overseas-territories.pdf)
attachment_1_title: DfT's work with the Overseas Territories

title: Penfold Review of non-planning consents
summary: Identifying measures to reduce the regulatory burden imposed on developers by the need to obtain additional consents and approvals after they have secured the grant of planning permission for their development proposals.
body:
## Summary

The Penfold Review of Non-Planning Consents was commissioned the Department of Business Innovation and Skills (BIS). The Review was charged with the identification of measures to reduce the regulatory burden imposed on developers by the need to obtain additional consents and approvals after they have secured the grant of planning permission for their development proposals. Such requirements cause delay and costs. On occasion, these can render the development concerned non-viable.

## Download the documents

  * [Penfold Review of non-planning consents (PDF, 305 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/penfold-review-non-planning-consents/penfold-review-non-planning-consents.pdf)

## Related documents

  * [Written Ministerial Statement: Implementation of the Penfold Review](/news/statements/greening-20120716b/)
attachment_1_title: Penfold Review of non-planning consents

title: People with severe temporary impairments advice to local authorities
summary: Using existing powers to help meet the mobility needs of people with severe temporary mobility issues.
body:
## Summary

This is an advice note to local authorities. It concerns how they can use existing powers to help meet the mobility needs of people with severe temporary mobility issues who do not qualify under the Blue Badge scheme's eligibility criteria.

## Download the documents

  * [People with severe temporary impairments - an advice note to local authorities (PDF, 69 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/people-with-severe-temporary-impairments/advice-note.pdf)

title: Criminal record checks in the aviation sector regulated by DfT
summary: Criminal record checks can play a key role in your personnel security regime, both at the pre-employment stage and as a tool in personnel security aftercare.
body:
## Development pool 

The Government announced its decisions on the Development Pool of local major transport schemes on 29 November and 14 December 2011. We are today publishing an update document setting out the process in more detail. For the 41 schemes where decisions have been announced, we are publishing the Department's internal assessment of the bids using the 5 elements of the Transport Business Case and the individual funding offer letters for each scheme. Some information has been redacted where it might prejudice ongoing financial considerations.

On 21 March 2012 the Government announced its decision on the bid received for the Bexhill to Hastings Link Road. The Department's assessment of the bid and funding offer letter are now included in the list below.

On 10 May the Department notified Rotherham MBC that DfT would not provide funding for the Waverley Link Road scheme. The Department's decision letter is included in the list below.

  * [Investment in Local Major Transport Schemes: 2nd Update (PDF - 96 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/local-authority-major-transport-schemes/investment-local-major-update-dec2011.pdf)

title: National security vetting in the regulated transport industry
summary: About national security vetting (including the counter terrorist check) in the transport sector regulated by the DfT
body:
## Contents

  * Summary
  * What is national security vetting?
  * Application process
  * Relevant offences
  * Appeal procedures
  * Request for appointment of a counter-signatory

## Summary

Information for nominated industry sponsors and applicants about national security vetting (including the counter terrorist check) in the transport sector regulated by the Department for Transport.

Any questions should be directed to the Vetting Team Manager at [personnelsecurity@dft.gsi.gov.uk](mailto:personnelsecurity@dft.gsi.gov.uk)

## What is national security vetting?

The Cabinet Office provides advice and guidance for individuals who are subject to HMG recruitment and national security vetting controls:

  * [HMG Personnel Security Controls (PDF, 293 KB)](http://www.cabinetoffice.gov.uk/sites/default/files/resources/hmg-personnel-security-controls.pdf)

The Department for Transport (DfT) has defined in Directions the specific roles and duties across the regulated transport industry for which national security vetting (NSV) is required, as well as the type of clearance required. These Directions have not been published for reasons of national security but have been made available to the industry.

Please note that only defined roles are eligible for NSV clearance and that all applications must be made through a nominated industry sponsor authorised by DfT. Speculative applications will not be considered.

## Application process

### Instructions

1. This process is for individuals in the regulated transport sector who have been directly instructed by their employer or DfT that they require a national security vetting (NSV) clearance.

Please note that applications must be made through a nominated industry sponsor authorised by DfT. Speculative applications will **not** be considered.

2. Applicants should read the latest HM government Personnel Security and National Security Vetting Policy Statement prior to completing the security questionnaire

  * [HMG Personnel Security Controls (PDF, 293 KB)](http://www.cabinetoffice.gov.uk/sites/default/files/resources/hmg-personnel-security-controls.pdf)

3. The HMG Baseline Personnel Security Standard (BPSS) in recruitment practice, outlined in the statement above, must also be met. However, please note that a basic criminal records disclosure from Disclosure Scotland or Access Northern Ireland is **not** required prior to submitting the questionnaire.

4. **The application process is moving to an online system.Details to follow soon.**

## Relevant offences

**These offences apply only to applications for national security vetting in the transport sector regulated by the Department for Transport (DfT).**

**Relevant offences for use against a criminal record check (basic disclosure) to complete a background check in the regulated aviation sector are availalbe at [disqualifying convictions aviation](/publications/crc-disqualifying-convictions-aviation).**

All types of national security vetting (NSV) include a check of criminal record information. 

Please note that a conviction for a relevant offence listed below is **not** necessarily a bar to NSV clearance. DfT will consider on a case-by-case basis whether any conviction is relevant to suitability for the post and type of clearance for which the individual is applying. 

DfT, in carrying out checks as part of the NSV process, will consider both spent _and_ unspent convictions. It will also include police cautions and additional information held on local police records and considered to be relevant to the post and type of clearance for which the individual is applying.

Lists of relevant offences for the regulated transport industry were drawn up by DfT in consultation with industry and the police. Where appropriate, DfT may take into account offences other than those in these lists. More weight may be attached to one or more offences as an indicator of possible unsuitability where they are serious, repeated and recent.

Failure to declare criminal convictions on the security questionnaire may also give rise to serious concerns.

### Lists of relevant offences for the transport industry regulated by DfT

  * [Offences list for England and Wales](/publications/crc-relevant-offences-england-wales/)
  * [Offences list for Scotland](/publications/crc-relevant-offences-scotland/)
  * [Offences list for Northern Ireland](/publications/crc-relevant-offences-northern-ireland/)
  * [Offences list under Military Law](/publications/crc-relevant-offences-military-law/)

## Appeal procedures

The Cabinet Office outlines the appeals procedures for national security vetting (NSV):

  * [HMG Personnel Security Controls (PDF, 293 KB)](http://www.cabinetoffice.gov.uk/sites/default/files/resources/hmg-personnel-security-controls.pdf)

The Department for Transport (DfT) also operates a system by which an applicant may appeal for a Certificate of Disregard where they have a conviction which they feel should be disregarded for the purposes of issuing the necessary security clearance for the specified role. 

The procedure for applying for a Certificate of Disregard is as follows:

  * An applicant whose criminal record certificate has revealed one or more relevant convictions, and who wishes for their case to be considered by the DfT (acting in the name of the Secretary of State), shall provide DfT with information in support of their application for a Certificate of Disregard. The information shall include the valid criminal record certificate and any documentation available from the criminal trial that led to the conviction(s). It may also include a note from the pass applicant's solicitor, trade union or other representative. 

The documentation shall include a character reference, which may be from a sponsoring employer or any person or body that the applicant considers is relevant and is of suitable standing. If from an employer it should be from someone with direct management responsibility for the applicant and should state the date upon which the applicant commenced work for the employer or is due to commence work. The character reference should state

  * when the referee became aware of the pass applicant's conviction(s);
  * the referee's experience of the applicant in terms of his overall integrity, and
  * anything else which reflects upon the applicant's suitability to hold a level of national security vetting.

The application may contain any other information that the applicant considers relevant in demonstrating his or her good character before/since the conviction(s). It shall be submitted under cover of the form below.

  * [Application for a Department for Transport certificate to disregard a conviction (DOC, 31 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/personnel-security-nsv/application-for-a-dft-certificate-to-disregard-a-conviction.doc)

The applicant should forward the application and supporting documentation detailed in Step A, to:  
Vetting Team  
Department for Transport  
Zone 2/26  
Great Minster House  
33 Horseferry Road  
London  
SW1P 4DR

DfT will reach a view on whether the conviction(s) may be disregarded for the purposes of granting the security clearance. Convictions for offences that involve violence, dishonesty or abuse of trust are disqualifying offences as they can indicate that the individual may be vulnerable to pressure or improper influence or liable to commit a breach of security. DfT will consider the information supplied by the applicant and the relevant circumstances of the case, including (but not limited to) the age of the conviction(s) and its seriousness. DfT may need to request additional information from the applicant, such as more details about the conviction.

Where DfT does not require additional information from the pass applicant in order to determine an application, it will endeavour to issue a determination letter to the pass applicant within 28 days of the application to disregard a conviction(s) being received, or will contact the applicant within the 28 day period to inform the applicant as to when he or she can expect a reply. Notice of the decision will be given to the applicant. Where a decision is made that the disqualifying conviction may be disregarded, a Certificate of Disregard will be issued to the pass applicant. The Certificate of Disregard will state that the disqualifying conviction(s) may be permanently disregarded for the purposes of issuing a level of security clearance and confirm that the applicant has indeed received that clearance.

## Request for appointment of a counter-signatory

A counter-signatory is required for a directed party to pass responsibility for managing NSV applications to a contractor.

  * [Request for appointment of a counter-signatory for the purposes of protective transport personnel security regulation](/publications/personnel-security-nsv-counter-signatory/)

## Related documents

  * [Criminal Record Checks in the regulated aviation sector](/publications/personnel-security-aviation-crc)
  * [Personnel security and national security vetting](/topics/security/personnel-security/)
  * [Personnel security publications](/publications?tag=personnel-security)
  * [Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1974](/publications/personnel-security-aviation-crc/#roa)
attachment_1_title: Application for a Department for Transport certificate to disregard a conviction

title: Request for appointment of a counter-signatory for the purposes of protective transport personnel security regulation
summary: Application form for a directed party to pass responsibility for managing NSV applications to a contractor.
body:
## Summary

The proforma is a written agreement between the directed party and their contractor or supplier.

It provides the Department for Transport (DfT) with:

  * a record that the contractor or supplier is authorised by the directed party to carry out pre-employment background checks and NSV application management on direct employees of the directed party
  * written confirmation from a directed party that they authorise the contractor or supplier to act as a counter-signatory on completed NSV security questionnaires
  * confirmation that the directed party is aware of their responsibilities regarding NSV ie they are responsible for the actions of the contractor or supplier
  * an undertaking that the contractor or supplier does and will NOT directly employ and manage staff on behalf of the directed party

The proforma should be downloaded and text replaced with the name of the directed party or contractor/supplier where indicated. It should then be printed, signed by the directed party and returned to:

Vetting Team  
Department for Transport  
Zone 2/26  
Great Minster House  
33 Horseferry Road  
London  
SW1P 4DR

## Download the proforma

  * [Request for appointment of a counter-signatory for the purposes of protective transport personnel security regulation](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/personnel-security-nsv-counter-signatory/form.doc)
attachment_1_title: Request for appointment of a counter-signatory for the purposes of protective transport personnel security regulation

title: CPNI personnel security resource list
summary: The CPNI is government authority that provides protective physical, personnel and information security advice to the national infrastructure.
body:
## What is CPNI?

The Centre for the Protection of National Infrastructure (CPNI) is government authority that provides protective physical, personnel and information security advice to the national infrastructure.

  * [Centre for the Protection of National Infrastructure](http://www.cpni.gov.uk/)

## CPNI resources

### Risk assessment for personnel security

This CPNI guide focuses on employees, their access to an organisation's assets, the risks they could pose to the organisation and the sufficiency of countermeasures. This aids a thorough and balanced response and the allocation of resources in cost effective ways commensurate with risk.

  * [Risk assessment for personnel security: a guide (third edition) (PDF)](http://www.cpni.gov.uk/documents/publications/2010/2010037-risk_assment_ed3.pdf)

### Pre employment screening and document verification

CPNI pages providing information on screening, a fundamentally important element of any personnel security regime. Offers advice and guidance on verifying identity, the right to work, employment history and qualifications, and criminal records.

  * [Good practice in pre employment screening and document verification](http://www.cpni.gov.uk/advice/Personnel-security1/Screening/)

### Ongoing personnel security

This CPNI guide focuses on what can be done to ensure that the personnel security regime continues past the recruitment stage. It covers security culture, line management, contracting, manipulation, controlling and monitoring access and investigating employees.

  * [Ongoing personnel security: a good practice guide (second edition) (PDF)](http://www.cpni.gov.uk/documents/publications/2010/2010021-gpg_ongoing_personnel_security.pdf)

### Managing the disclosure of employee-related information

This CPNI document provides guidance to employers on how to manage employee-related information disclosed to them by the security authorities. Whether the disclosure is about a member of staff working in a sensitive area suspected of being in contact with terrorists, or is about an employee managing the organisation's finances who is falsely claiming benefits, there are common measures which the employer can take to help manage the risk.

  * [Managing the disclosure of employee-related information: a good practice guide for employers (PDF)](http://www.cpni.gov.uk/documents/publications/2009/2009021-gpg_disclosure_employee.pdf)

### Online social networking

A CPNI/CESG publication which offers an holistic view of the risks associated with social networking and microblogging sites (including content, malware, phishing and spam and social interactions) and gives guidance on appropriate countermeasures.

  * [Online social networking: good practice guide (PDF)](http://www.cpni.gov.uk/documents/publications/2010/2010032-gpg_online_social_networking.pdf)

### Investigating employees of concern

This CPNI guide offers factors to consider and best practice on all stages of an investigation.

  * [Investigating employees of concern: a good practice guide (PDF)](http://www.cpni.gov.uk/documents/publications/2011/2011mar34-persec-investigating_employees_of_concern.pdf)

### CPNI security awareness campaign kit

Designed to help security teams promote best practice security messages across any organisation in the national infrastructure, the kit comes in CD format and includes presentations and customisable posters for your company. To obtain a copy of the campaign kit contact [enquiries@cpni.gsi.gov.uk](mailto:enquiries@cpni.gsi.gov.uk)

### CPNI personnel security DVD in hindsight

This 25 minute DVD includes chapters on recruitment, ongoing personnel security and exit procedures, and illustrates common mistakes and oversights through case study. The DVD is available by contacting [enquiries@cpni.gsi.gov.uk](mailto:enquiries@cpni.gsi.gov.uk)

### CPNI transport advisors 

CPNI transport advisors work jointly with DfT to reduce the vulnerability of the national infrastructure to terrorism and other threats, keeping the UK's essential services safer. The advisors provide advice and guidance on physical, personnel and information security and work with individual companies, transport modal sectors or across the industry. For further information please contact [enquiries@cpni.gsi.gov.uk](mailto:enquiries@cpni.gsi.gov.uk)

### CPNI training courses 

CPNI offer a range of courses including 'Risk assessment', 'Pre-employment screening' and 'Resolving suspicions about employees of concern'. These are intended for all sectors within the Critical National Infrastructure, including transport. Delegates must be sponsored by their CPNI sector advisor (see above). For more information and to request the full CPNI training brochure [trainingandevents@cpni.gsi.gov.uk](mailto:trainingandevents@cpni.gsi.gov.uk?subject=CPNI%20training%20brochure)

### CPNI security culture review and evaluation (SeCuRE) tool

SeCuRE is designed to help organisations and companies identify and develop appropriate security cultures, a key part of managing and minimising the risks of insider action because organisational culture affects and reflects the way that people think and the way they behave. The tool comes on CD format and consists of two questionnaires supported by a software analysis tool which provides a feedback report for security professionals and senior managers. A comprehensive guidance document aids implementing the tool and interpreting results. SeCuRE requires support resources from CPNI and can be obtained on request from your CPNI advisor through [enquiries@cpni.gsi.gov.uk](mailto:enquiries@cpni.gsi.gov.uk).

### Transport employers terms and conditions of employment

This guidance is intended for use by employers to ensure that conduct and behaviour which could constitute a security concern is adequately accounted for in terms and conditions of employment.

  * [Guidance for transport employers on including security-related conduct and behaviour issues in terms and conditions of employment](/publications/security-related-conduct-and-behaviour-issues-in-terms-and-conditions-of-employment/)

title: Port facility security officer training - list of approved training providers
summary: A list of approved training providers for Port Security Officer training (PFSO)
body:
## Summary

All Port Facility Security Officers (PFSOs) in the UK must attend an approved training course run by an accredited company. The following companies have thus far been accredited and received approval from the Department for Transport to conduct PFSO training courses on behalf of the industry. All courses may be subject to unannounced audits by the Department for Transport to ensure quality control. Additional training providers will be added as they receive approval.

## List of approved training providers

[PFSO training - approved training providers (PDF, 60 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/port-facility-security-officer-training/approved-training-providers.pdf)

To apply to become an accredited training provider please contact:-  
Maritime Training Manager  
Department for Transport  
Great Minster House  
33 Horseferry Road  
London SW1P 4DR  
Telephone 0300 330 3000  
email: [maritimesecurity@dft.gsi.gov.uk](mailto:maritimesecurity@dft.gsi.gov.uk)

Details of training for Ship Security Officers (SSOs) and Company Security Officers (CSOs) can be found on the [MCA website](http://www.dft.gov.uk/mca/mcga07-home/mcga-mgn).

title: Making the connection: the plug-in vehicle infrastructure strategy
summary: A clear vision for infrastructure and the steps we are taking to remove barriers for those wishing to invest in, provide or benefit from plug-in vehicle infrastructure.
body:
## Introduction

This strategy sets out a clear vision for infrastructure and the steps we are taking to remove barriers for those wishing to invest in, provide or benefit from plug-in vehicle infrastructure.

It describes how we are:

  * using the Plugged-In Places trials as a central mechanism to inform the development of business models
  * removing barriers to the market
  * producing a favourable environment for private investment
  * helping the consumer by ensuring all public infrastructure is easy to access

## Download the strategy

  * [Making the Connection: the Plug-In Vehicle Infrastructure Strategy (PDF, 7168 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/making-the-connection-the-plug-in-vehicle-infrastructure-strategy/plug-in-vehicle-infrastructure-strategy.pdf)
  * [Making the Connection: the Plug-In Vehicle Infrastructure Strategy (DOC, 2048 MB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/making-the-connection-the-plug-in-vehicle-infrastructure-strategy/plug-in-vehicle-infrastructure-strategy.doc)
  * [Executive summary - Welsh translation (PDF, 311 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/making-the-connection-the-plug-in-vehicle-infrastructure-strategy/plug-in-vehicle-infrastructure-strategy-welsh.pdf)
  * [Executive summary - Welsh translation (DOC, 125 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/making-the-connection-the-plug-in-vehicle-infrastructure-strategy/plug-in-vehicle-infrastructure-strategy-welsh.doc)

## Related documents

  * [Taking charge press release, 30 June 2011](/news/press-releases/dft-press-20110630)
  * [Low emission vehicles](/topics/sustainable/olev/)

body:

International air services (apart from services within the European Union) are governed by the provisions of inter-governmental instruments. title: Potholes review prevention and a better cure
summary: Final report of the review into the pothole problem.
body:
## Summary

In April 2011 the Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Transport announced a review into the problem of potholes. A progress report was published in December, and the final report is now available. The Review has considered how local highway authorities deal with potholes, as well as wider stakeholder views and implications. It makes 17 recommendations that will, if implemented, provide an improvement in highway maintenance and reduce the number of potholes occurring. There are three key messages in the report:

  * Prevention is better than cure;
  * Right first time for better repairs; and
  * Clarity for the public.

## Download the document

  * [Potholes Review - Prevention and a better cure (PDF, 4,987 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/pothole-review/pothole-review.pdf)
  * [Appendix B1: Case studies (PDF, 318KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/pothole-review/appendix-b1-case-studies.pdf)
  * [Appendix B2: Technical notes (PDF, 159KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/pothole-review/appendix-b2-technical-notes.pdf)
  * [Appendix B3: Guidance documents (PDF, 117KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/pothole-review/appendix-b3-guidance-documents.pdf)
  * [Appendix B4: Research projects (PDF, 64KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/pothole-review/appendix-b4-research-projects.pdf)
  * [Appendix B5: National highway sector schemes (PDF, 54KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/pothole-review/appendix-b5-national-highway-sector-schemes.pdf)
  * [Appendix B6: Highways authorities product approval scheme (HAPAS) (PDF, 74KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/pothole-review/appendix-b6-highways-approval-scheme.pdf)

## Related documnets

  * [Pothole Review - Prevention and a better cure press release](/news/press-releases/dft-press-20120410a)
  * [Highways Maintenance Efficiency Programme (HMEP)](/hmep)

title: Potholes review progress report
summary: Current progress report on the Potholes review, the final report of the review will be released in 2012.
body:
## Summary

In April a review of potholes was announced by the Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Transport under the Highways Maintenance Efficiency Programme. The final report is due next year, but a progress report is now being published. The progress report identifies the key principles and strategies regarding potholes, and a number of areas for further work. These include providing improved guidance to local authorities on prioritising key roads, adopting a whole-life approach to road maintenance and using the right technology and materials.

## Download the report documents

  * [Progress report: Potholes review (PDF 454 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/potholes-review-progress-report/potholes-review-progress-report.pdf)
attachment_1_title: Progress report: Potholes review

title: Department for Transport privacy policy
summary: How the Department uses and protects information we collect about you when you visit this website and other websites that we manage.
body:
This policy:

  * Explains the privacy policy for the Department for Transport and its agencies, and explains how we will use and protect any information we collect about you when you visit this website and other websites that we manage
  * Provides fuller information about the personal data that is collected by the Department's Agencies as part of their business operations

The Department has published an information charter on this website, which sets out the standards you can expect from us when we handle your personal information. It also explains how you can ask to see a copy of any personal information that we are processing about you.

  * [DfT information charter](/publications/information-charter/)

Whilst the Department for Transport is a single data controller for the purposes of the Data Protection Act 1998, each of our agencies has separate arrangements in place for managing compliance with that Act. The information charter will tell you who to contact if you have any concerns about the way any part of the Department is processing your personal data.

## Information collected from our website

This website will not capture or store your personal information without your knowledge, other than to log your IP address and session information (which includes the duration of your visit to our site and the type of web browser used). We may use this data in aggregate form to help us improve the operation and appeal of our site.

Where you are asked to provide information about yourself when you visit certain parts of our site, we will make clear what we want to use that information for. We will keep the information for the length of time needed to provide the service or information you have requested, or in accordance with the law or government policy.

## Services provided by the executive agencies

### DSA

  * [Privacy policy for services provided by DSA](/publications/dsa-privacy)

**For DSA FOI requests**

Knowledge and Information team -- FOI  
The Axis Building  
112 Upper Parliament Street  
Nottingham, NG1 6LP  
[foi@dsa.gsi.gov.uk](mailto:foi@dsa.gsi.gov.uk)

**For DSA subject access requests**

Knowledge and Information team -- subject access requests  
The Axis Building  
112 Upper Parliament Street  
Nottingham, NG1 6LP  
[dataprotection@dsa.gsi.gov.uk](mailto:dataprotection@dsa.gsi.gov.uk)

### Department for Transport central

The Data Protection Officer  
Department for Transport  
D/04, Ashdown House  
Sedlescombe Road North  
St Leonards on Sea,   
East Sussex, TN37 7GA  
[informationhandling@dft.gsi.gov.uk](mailto:informationhandling@dft.gsi.gov.uk)

  * [What you need to know about making an FOI request to DfT](/foi/making-an-foi-request/)

## How to make a complaint

Our information charter provides details about what you should do if you are unhappy with our service and wish to make a complaint to any part of the Department.

  * [DfT information charter](/publications/information-charter/)

## Changes to this privacy policy

If this privacy policy changes, we will update this page.

title: Productive use of rail travel time and the valuation of travel time savings for business travellers - final report
summary: The productive use of rail travel time and the valuation of travel time savings for business travellers.
body:
## Summary

This survey-based research study was commissioned by the Department for Transport to provide evidence to inform its consideration of how to treat of business travel time savings in appraisal guidance. Its objective was to provide potential estimates of the use of travel time on trains by UK rail business travellers, together with and of the impact that journey time savings would have on their level of activity during the day and the value of these to both the employer and to the employee. As the report acknowledges, the research related only to current rail business travellers and current travel conditions, and longer term impacts are not considered in detail.  

## Download the report

  * [Productive use of rail travel time and the valuation of travel time savings for business travellers - final report (PDF, 2.2MB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/productive-use-of-travel-time/productive-use-of-travel-time.pdf)

## Related documents

  * [Strategy unit paper - review of the value of time assumptions for business travellers](/publications/strategy-review-value-time-assumptions/)

title: Road Safety Partnership Grant programme summary report of impact of round two projects and progress on later projects
summary: Summary of outcomes and key learning points from the projects which benefited from the Road Safety Partnership Grant programme.
body:
## Summary

To further support local highway authorities in delivering casualty reduction targets locally, an annual £4million Road Safety Partnership Grant programme was launched at the end of October 2006, inviting bids from all local highway authorities in England.

The programme promotes a collaborative approach to all aspects of delivering enhanced road safety. In particular it aims to encourage partnerships between traditional road safety professionals and other service providers including the education sector, the health sector, the fire service, the youth service and the voluntary sector. It also hopes to stimulate road safety schemes which produce environmental and regeneration benefits.

This report provides a summary of outcomes and highlights the key learning points from the projects which benefited from the Road Safety Partnership Grant programme round two, which ran for up to two years from April 2008. It also provides brief summaries of those projects which were agreed in the following round, which are due to complete in March 2011.

## Download the report

  * [The Road Safety Partnership Grant programme summary report of impact of round two projects and progress on later projects (PDF, 251 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/pgr-roadsafety-rspg-impactofround2projectsreport-pdf/report.pdf)

## Previous reports

  * [Road Safety Partnership Grant round one 2007-09 schemes summary report (PDF, 548 KB)](http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20110503225627/http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/roadsafety/rspg/round-one.pdf)
  * [Road Safety Partnership Grant 2007-2009 schemes headline impact report (PDF, 429 KB)](http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20110503225629/http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/roadsafety/rspg/impact_report.pdf)
attachment_1_title: The Road Safety Partnership Grant programme summary report of impact of round two projects and progress on later projects

title: Protocol - the role of air, marine and rail accident Investigation branches and their relationship with the Department for Transport
summary: Protocol of work for the three accident investigation branches (AIBs).
body:
## Summary

The Air, Marine and Rail Accident Investigation Branches (AAIB, MAIB and RAIB) are stand-alone branches of the Department for Transport (DfT). Their general aims are to improve the safety of their respective sectors and to prevent accidents and incidents.

The three Accident Investigation Branches (AIBs) also fulfill the UK's duty under the respective EU Safety Directives to establish permanent bodies to undertake independent investigation of rail, maritime and air accidents. For all three Branches, the sole objective of investigating an accident is to determine its circumstances and causes, with the aims of improving safety and avoiding future accidents. It is not the purpose to apportion liability, nor to apportion blame.

## Download the document

  * [Protocol - The Role of Air, Marine and Rail Accident Investigation Branches and their relationship with the Department for Transport](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/protocol-accident-investigation-branches/aib-protocol.pdf)
attachment_1_title: Protocol - The Role of Air, Marine and Rail Accident Investigation Branches and their relationship with the Department for Transport

title: Qualitative research with residents
summary: In 2010 in-depth qualitative research was undertaken with a sample of residents in Cycling City and Towns programme areas.
body:
## Summary

As part of the ongoing evaluation of the Cycling City and Towns (CCT) programme, in-depth qualitative research was undertaken in 2010 with a sample of residents in the CCT programme areas to explore their experiences, attitudes and behaviours in relation to cycling and the cycling investment in their towns.

The research aimed to provide evidence to help interpret the findings of the post-intervention survey when the results are available in 2013. In the shorter term, it aims to contribute to our understanding of cycling behaviours and how people may best be encouraged to consider cycling as a viable transport option.

For more information on the CCT programme and its evaluation, please see the Department's pages concerning [evaluation of the Cycling City and Towns Programme](/publications/cycling-city-and-towns-programme).

## Download the documents

  * [Qualitative research with residents (PDF, 7500 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/cct-qualitative-research-residents/cct-qualitative-research.pdf)

title: Quiet Deliveries Demonstration Scheme
summary: Ways of allowing HGV vehicles to make quiet out of hours deliveries.
body:
HGV deliveries in residential areas are often constrained during night-time and/or weekend periods. However, this increases traffic and carbon emissions at peak hours. 

The Quiet Deliveries Demonstration Scheme (QDDS) scheme has investigated the types of constraint, the requirements for seeking a relaxation of delivery hours and the potential benefits of introducing quiet out-of-hours deliveries that do not create a disturbance to local residents.

title: Rail interoperability TSI FAQ
summary: Frequently asked questions about Technical Specifications for Interoperability (TSIs)
body:
## Frequently asked questions about Technical Specifications for Interoperability ("TSIs")

[Detailed guidance on the application of TSIs and the implementation of interoperability](http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/+/www.dft.gov.uk//pgr/rail/interoperabilityandstandards/interoperabilityfaqs/interoperabilityhelpnotes/)

If you are still unable to find an answer to your query, please email us at [interoperability@dft.gsi.gov.uk](mailto:interoperability@dft.gsi.gov.uk). 

  * What is a TSI?
  * What is the role of TSIs
  * What is a status of TSIs?
  * How are TSIs developed?
  * What do TSIs contain?
  * What are "Specific Cases"?
  * How are errors in TSIs dealt with?

## What is a TSI?

A TSI is a common, harmonised, technical standard required to satisfy the essential requirements of interoperability which include safety, reliability and availability, health, environmental protection and technical compatibility.

Depending on their scope, TSIs may also contain other specific requirements relating to either "structural" subsystems (such as infrastructure, rolling stock, energy, and control/command and signalling) or "functional" subsystems (such as maintenance, traffic operation and management and telematics applications for passengers and freight services).     

TSIs are prepared by the European Railway Agency ("ERA") under a mandate from the European Commission.  The mandate specifies the format which TSIs must conform to and the method that ERA must use to prepare them. 

## What is the role of TSIs

A Contracting Entity, which has responsibility for the management of any project, must ensure that the essential requirements of safety, reliability and availability, health, environmental protection and technical compatibility are met. ** **  
The application of TSIs removes the need for individual Contracting Entities to decide how the essential requirements should be met since they set out the means whereby, for the specific situations within their scope, these will be met.  TSIs also drive standardisation by mandating interfaces and assessment methodologies.  

The TSI framework is supplemented by [NNTRs](/topics/rail-interoperability-standards/common-technical-standards-for-rail-interoperability/notified-national-technical-rules) which, in respect of open (unresolved) points in the TSI, fulfill the role of defining how the essential requirements will be met.

## What is the status of TSIs?

TSIs are "Decisions" under European Community Law and have effect as if they were domestic regulations (secondary legislation).   As such they are binding on Member States, and because the Railways (Interoperability) Regulations 2011 make specific reference to TSIs and apply them for domestic purposes, their requirements are binding on the rail industry in the United Kingdom.

## How are TSIs developed?

TSIs are prepared by the European Railway Agency ("ERA") under a mandate from the European Commission.  The mandate specifies the format of the TSI and the method that the ERA must use to prepare it.

Once a work programme is agreed, ERA establishes Drafting Group on which each National Safety Authority has a seat as well as experts from a number of relevant European Railway organisations.  The Group must prepare a document that matches the standard framework and content of a TSI.

Once the Drafting Group has completed its task, ERA sends the final draft to the European Commission, for consideration, amendment, and acceptance by the Railway Interoperability and Safety Committee ("RISC").  Once ratified by a vote at RISC, and following subsequent approval by the Council and Parliament of the European Union, the European Commission issues the TSI as a Decision which then becomes binding upon Member States.

This process normally takes around three years and the Rail Safety and Standards Board has published [Guidance on TSI Development](http://www.rssb.co.uk/EUROPE/Pages/TSI.aspx) and an associated Checklist [link "[checklist](http://www.rssb.co.uk/SiteCollectionDocuments/rgs/005_Guidance_TSI_drafting_checklist_issue_2.pdf)" .

## What do TSIs contain?

The structure and content of a TSI is prescribed in the Interoperability Directives and can be summarised as:** **

**Chapter 2** - establishes its scope; 

**Chapter 3** - specifies the essential requirements for the relevant subsystem; 

**Chapter 4** - lists the basic parameters of the subsystem necessary to meet the essential requirements and its interfaces with other subsystems.  It also specifies the functional and technical specifications which must be met and its interfaces to achieve specified performance; 

**Chapter 5** - determines the Interoperability Constituents and their interfaces necessary to achieve interoperability; 

**Chapter 6** - describes the procedures for assessing the conformity or suitability for use of Interoperability Constituents and for performing the EC Verification of the subsystem; and 

**Chapter 7** - describes the implementing provisions in certain specific cases, including recommendations regarding the time objectives for the transition from the existing to the final situation where there is full compliance with the TSIs (referred to as either an implementation plan or strategy).  This chapter frequently contains the answers sought by Contracting Entities and Notified Bodies to difficult compliance questions. 

## What are "Specific Cases"?

Specific cases are provisions made in TSIs to deal with particular circumstances prevailing in a particular Member State.  For example, Great Britain has specific cases in the Infrastructure and Rolling Stock TSIs in relation to the structure gauge because our infrastructure is different to that found in mainland Europe.

Specific cases for all Member States are included in Chapter 7 of each TSI.** **

## How are errors in TSIs dealt with?

Errors in TSIs may be either "critical" or "minor" in scope.** **

An error in a TSI is **critical** if it:

  * prevents the completion of subsystem or interoperable constituent design; ** **
  * prevents the conformity assessment of the subsystem or the interoperable constituent; 
  * prevents the placing into service of the subsystem or the placing onto the market of the interoperable constituent; 
  * prevents the interoperability of the subsystem or the interoperable constituent 
  * contributes to unsafe operation not foreseen as part of the certification of the subsystem and / or the interoperable constituent; or 
  * contributes directly to an accident or incident. 

The European Commission has put in place a formal and "rapid" procedure for resolving critical errors.  If you think that your difficulties arise from one of the scenarios described, please email us at [interoperability@dft.gsi.gov.uk](mailto:interoperability@dft.gsi.gov.uk) to explore whether this is the best route to pursue.

Where the error has arisen because a specification is impossible to apply in one Member State or in one specified (but generic) situation, then the European Commission can be petitioned for a Specific Case to be made and included in the TSI.  This is likely to be the device that is used to deal with some of the critical errors.

## Non-critical errors

Other errors are regarded as minor errors, and it is the Department's responsibility to resolve non-critical errors once they are brought to its attention.  As with critical errors, please email [interoperability@dft.gsi.gov.uk](mailto:interoperability@dft.gsi.gov.uk) to discuss the problem. 

Minor errors are regarded as less urgent than critical errors and will be addressed in the routine review of the TSI.

The Rail Safety and Standards Board has established a log to capture information relating to problems which have been encountered during the application of TSIs in the United Kingdom at [www.rssb.co.uk/EUROPE/Pages/TSI.aspx](http://www.rssb.co.uk/EUROPE/Pages/TSI.aspx). 

## Related documents

  * [Rail interoperability and standards](/topics/rail-interoperability-standards)
  * [Rail interoperability consultations](/consultations?topic=rail-interoperability)
  * [Rail interoperability publications](/publications?topic=rail-interoperability)

## Help downloading or accessing files

  * See [help with downloads](/site/help/downloads)
  * [Contact us](/about/contact) for an alternative format
"

title: Implementation plans for technical specifications for  interoperability
summary: Published implementation plans for Technical Specifications for  Interoperability (“TSIs”) in Great    Britain.
body:
## TSIs

Published implementation plans for Technical Specifications for Interoperability ("TSIs") in Great Britain.

One of the key elements of the strategy for interoperability is to create realistic and deliverable long-term implementation plans for each TSI.  It is envisaged that these will be developed in consultation with stakeholders and require Ministerial sign off.  They will be essential to:

  * understand and set out the business case for migration towards the widespread use of interoperability;
  * strategically plan for the development of the future network

## Published Plans 

  *   [ERTMS National Implementation Plan (PDF, 570 KB)](http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/+/http://www.dft.gov.uk/adobepdf/165234/349552/ukertmsplan.pdf)

The introduction of the European Railway Traffic Management System ("ERTMS") is mandated by the Control, Command & Signalling TSI.  The system will progressively replace conventional signalling over the next 15 - 20 years.  A lot of the lineside structures and equipment that are part of our landscape will become redundant, and start to disappear, with trains instead being controlled by radio signals. 

The ERTMS implementation plan focuses on implementation of Global System for Mobile communications - Railway (GSM-R) and European Train Control System in support of the introduction of ERTMS Level 2 without lineside signals.  The plan aligns with expected re-signalling dates and rolling stock replacement dates wherever possible to produce the most cost-effective outcome.

ERTMS is essential if the rail system is to meet the needs of its customers in the twenty-first century.  It will mean that capacity usage of our crowded rail network can be optimised, maintenance costs should be reduced, fuel usage can be optimised thus reducing the carbon footprint, the equipment will be less vulnerable to local damage and vandalism, and signal sighting issues associated with conventional systems cease to be a problem.

title: Rail interoperability notified bodies
summary: Rail interoperability notified bodies
body:
## NoBos

This is an overview of the role of Notified Bodies ("NoBos") which verify compliance with standards in the interoperability framework.

The design and construction of a new, renewed or upgraded railway subsystem must, under the [Railways (Interoperability) Regulations 2006](http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2006/397/contents/made)(RI), be verified by a NoBo as being compliant with applicable [Technical Specifications for Interoperability](/publications/rail-interoperability-tsi-catalogue) or [Notified National Technical Rules](/topics/rail-interoperability-standards/common-technical-standards-for-rail-interoperability/notified-national-technical-rules).

A NoBo must be appointed by a Contracting Entity before the completion of the design stage or before commencement of the manufacturing stage of a project, whichever is earlier.

  * [ Read an explanation of the NoBos role and how this fits into the broader interoperability framework (PDF 1024 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/interoperability/interoperability200.pdf)

NoBos are independent bodies assessed as meeting certain criteria under RIR, including competence, independence and integrity. In the United Kingdom, NoBos are appointed by the Secretary of State having considered advice from the [United Kingdom Accreditation Service](http://www.ukas.com) which also monitors their performance.

  * [NoBos doing work in the UK (PDF, 21 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/interoperability/notified-bodies.pdf)
  * [A list of all + is available from the European Commission](http://ec.europa.eu/enterprise/newapproach/nando/index.cfm?fuseaction=directive.notifiedbody&dir_id=30&type_dir=NO%20CPD&pro_id=99999&prc_id=99999&ann_id=99999&prc_anx=99999)

NoBo appointments are administered by the Department and more advice on the process can be obtained from [interoperability@dft.gsi.gov.uk](mailto:interoperability@dft.gsi.gov.uk)

## Non-UK NoBos

We have produced the following advice to assist NoBos appointed by another Member State wishing to work in the United Kingdom to support their integration and provide access to our Notified Body Forum which facilitates the exchange of best practice. 

  * [Guidance for NoBos wishing to work in the UK (PDF, 95 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/interoperability/nobo-member-state.pdf)

title: Rail interoperability strategy
summary: This is an outline of the strategic approach being taking to implement interoperability in Great Britain.
body:
This is an outline of the strategic approach being taking to implement interoperability in Great Britain. 

We have produced the following summary of the high-level strategy for the sustainable and cost-effective implementation of interoperability on the railway

  * [Interoperability Implementation Strategy - Summary (PDF, 32 KB)](http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/+/http://www.dft.gov.uk/adobepdf/165234/349552/fourpointsummary.pdf)

In broad terms, the strategy for the implementation of interoperability is to consider the development of infrastructure first, and by default, to ensure it is available for all operators to place their vehicles into service using the interoperability process. 

Planning for the implementation of interoperability is challenging and will require a persistent long-term vision, coupled with evidence based strategic decisions involving all relevant stakeholders.

title: Rail franchise change of control policy statement
summary: The Secretary of State's policy regarding requests for consent to changes of control under the terms of the relevant franchise agreement.
body:
From time to time, the Secretary of State is asked to approve changes of control of a franchisee. This note is a statement setting out the Secretary of State's policy when he receives requests for his consent to changes of control under the terms of the relevant franchise agreement.

## What is a change of control?

A change of control relates to a change in the identity of any person who "controls" the franchisee or franchise operator. "Control" for this purpose is defined in the franchise agreement. The definition contained in a recent franchise agreement is included at the appendix to this note.

## Why is it necessary to obtain the Secretary of State's consent to a change of control?

It is an Event of Default under the franchise agreement (for franchises on the new template it is paragraph 2.3 of Schedule 10.3) for a change to occur during the Franchise Term in the identity of any one person, or any two or more persons acting by agreement, who may Control the franchisee, without the consent of the Secretary of State. The prohibition is important because franchisees and franchise operators deliver front line public services. Rail franchises are vital to the government's delivery of its broader policy objectives on the environment, the economy, social inclusion and accessibility. Ensuring the continued success of a franchise is therefore a matter of legitimate public interest. All franchisees are vetted by the Secretary of State to ensure that they are financially robust and have a track record of successful delivery. The Secretary of State will wish to have confidence that the new owners will continue to honour their obligations under the franchise agreement and, as the success of a franchise is ultimately dependent on delivery by its people, in the quality of the proposed management team.

## What things are taken into account in considering whether to approve a change of control?

Except in the case of a change of control resulting from an intra-group restructuring, the Secretary of State will require a range of information from the prospective new owner. This will include the following:

### Financial and legal

  * copies of the acquiring company's group accounts for the past two years and any published interim accounts for the current or immediately preceding financial year;
  * details of the acquiring company's corporate structure;
  * copies of all constitutional documents of the acquiring company and its parents and any legislation under which it is incorporated.

### People

  * details of the proposed senior management team (including the board) which will be responsible for the franchise going forward, including details of their relevant experience and qualifications.

### Plans to honour franchise obligations

  * confirmation that the acquiring company has undertaken full due diligence in relation to the franchise and therefore understands the obligations it will be taking on in respect of that business;
  * a statement from the acquiring company of its intentions in relation to the performance of the existing franchisee's obligations under its franchise agreement and its plans for the long term future of the franchise;
  * details of any future plans in relation to the acquiring company or in relation to the group which may affect the franchise or the way in which the acquiring company conducts its business.

## Will the Secretary of State require anything else?

Yes, the Secretary of State will generally require the payment of a facilitation fee in consideration of the Secretary of State's consent, if granted, to all future changes of control of passenger rail franchises (where these do not result from intra-group restructurings). The fee will be levied on the person or persons in control of the franchisee or franchise operator before the change. The amount of the fee will generally be the greater of £1million or 5% of the value of the change of control of the franchise to the vendor. The proceeds will be invested in the passenger rail network. This fee is over and above the administration costs of processing an application for consent to a change of control. The administration fee shall be calculated by reference to the amount of time spent by officials on the proposed change of control and the Department's scale rates for different grades of staff as shall apply from time to time.

## On what basis is the Secretary of State requiring a facilitation fee?

The Secretary of State considers it appropriate to require payment of a facilitation fee because it is the reasonable expectation of the Secretary of State that a change of control represents a value to the vendor. The opportunity to realise that value is a product of the system of franchising established and maintained by Secretary of State at public expense, and the value of franchises is in many cases a product of substantial public subsidy. Therefore, the Secretary of State considers it appropriate that the public should also realise a benefit from a change of control. The Strategic Rail Authority, and prior to that the Office of Passenger Rail Franchising, used to require a passenger dividend - agreed infrastructure or service investments - in consideration for consent to a change of control. Passenger dividends were in substance and effect similar to the facilitation fee which the Secretary of State is now seeking as consideration for his/her consent to the change of control and for reinvestment in the railway network.

As mentioned above, the fee will generally be the greater of £1million or 5% of the value of the change of control of the franchise to the seller. The Secretary of State considers that this basis of calculation strikes an appropriate balance between realising the full commercial value of the Secretary of State's consent for the benefit of the public and avoiding undue interference in the market. There are likely to be very few, if any, cases where the value of the Secretary of State's consent to the seller is less than £1m or where the imposition of a facilitation fee of £1m would constitute undue interference in the market.

Sellers will have the opportunity to make representations in relation to the facilitation fee when applying for the Secretary of State's consent to a change of control.

In order to assess the value of the change of control to the vendor of the relevant entity which currently has control of the franchisee or franchise operator, and to enable a proper assessment of the level of the facilitation fee to be made, the vendor will be required to provide the Secretary of State with such information and assistance as he may reasonably require.

title: Rail passenger franchises
summary: List of invitations to tender let since 2005.
body:
## Summary

### Invitation to Tender let since 2005

DfT Rail Procurement formerly had a settled policy to publish franchise Invitation to Tenders (ITTs) once the franchise has commenced and the Public Register Franchise Agreement (PRFA) has been agreed between the relevant Train Operating Company and DfT. Following a review of that policy, in future, subject to the application of any exemptions under the FOI Act (eg commercial prejudice), DfT Rail Procurement now intends to make ITTs publicly available at the same time as the ITT is disclosed to pre qualified bidders.

  * [Clarification on additional Capacity in New Cross Country (PDF, 24 KB)](http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/+/http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/rail/passenger/invitationtotender/clarificationonadditi1.pdf)
  * [East Midlands franchise ITT (PDF, 466 KB)](http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/+/http://www.dft.gov.uk/pgr/rail/passenger/invitationtotender/integratedeastmidland.pdf)

title: Railway Byelaws
summary: The current national Railway Byelaws were made in 2005 by Statutory Instrument under section 219 of the Transport Act 2000 in 2005.
body:
## Summary

The current national Railway Byelaws were made in 2005 by Statutory Instrument under section 219 of the Transport Act 2000 in 2005. During September 2011, in accordance with section 46(5) of the Railways Act 2005, an amendment was made to the national Railway Byelaws.

The Amendment Order altered the definition of "railway"" in the national Railway Byelaws to remove from its scope all railway assets of Transport for London as well as trains, vehicles and any associated equipment which are for the time being used by a person for the purposes of providing railway services under an agreement with Transport for London, or any of its subsidiaries. It also removes the references to London Underground Limited and Tube Lines Limited from the list of excluded operators in Schedule 2 as the amendment to "railway" makes their inclusion in the Schedule superfluous.

This amendment allowed Transport for London to set its own byelaws covering such issues as a general alcohol ban on its network and also ensures that there will be a consistent approach to the application of byelaws where national rail and Transport for London services share stations and facilities.

## Download the document

  * [Railways Byelaws (PDF, 166 KB)](http://assets.dft.gov.uk/publications/railway-byelaws/railway-byelaws.pdf)

## Legislation

  * [Railway Byelaws Amendment Order 2011](http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2011/2213/contents/made)
  * [Railways Act 2005](http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2005/14/contents)
  * [Railways Act 2005 UK Statutory Instruments](http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi?title=Railways%20Act%202005)
  * [Transport Act 2000](http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2000/38/contents)
